node.title: Watch Livestream of Recently Discovered Comet Sharing Sky With Star Cluster
node.alt: A stock photo shows a man standing with a telescope against a night sky. Livestreams to watch comet C/2021 A1 Leonard are due this month.
node.description: The comet, named C/2021 A1 Leonard, will pass Earth for the first time in around 70,000 years in what's promised to be a "breathtaking" sight.
node.content:
["Astronomy fans will be able to watch a comet gliding past a star cluster this week in a rare skywatching event.", "This month, the comet C/2021 A1 Leonard is due to pass overhead for several days as it heads towards the sun for the first time in around 70,000 years.", "Sky at Night magazine reported it will peak in brightness on December 13, and has published charts highlighting its expected location in the sky relative to other celestial bodies over several days.", "In addition, the Virtual Telescope Project is due to host a livestream of the comet sharing a patch of night sky with a vast cluster of stars called Messier 3.", "The Virtual Telescope Project states that \"the view will be breathtaking.\" It will host the \"Comet Leonard & Messier 3 meeting\" livestream on its website here on December 3 at 3:00 a.m. UTC (10:00 p.m. ET, December 2).", "Comet C/2021 A1 Leonard was discovered at the start of this year by astronomer Gregory J. Leonard, a senior researcher at the Department of Planetary Sciences at the University of Arizona, at the Mount Lemmon Observatory in Arizona, according to Space.com.", "Its orbit is highly eccentric, meaning that it travels around the sun in a flat oval shape rather than a circular one.", "As such it is thought that it travels as far as 325 billion miles away from our sun, or around 3,500 times the distance between the sun and the Earth, Space.com reported.", "It takes a long time to complete this orbit\u201435,000 years either way, according to Sky and Telescope magazine.", "When C/2021 A1 Leonard appears close to Messier 3 this week, it will not actually be physically close to the star cluster. The comet will actually be around 3.6 light-minutes away and the star cluster 34,000 light years away, the Virtual Telescope Project notes\u2014but they'll look close in the sky from our perspective on Earth.", "Comets are frozen chunks of ice, gas and rock that are leftovers from the formation of the solar system.", "Their orbits sometimes see them come particularly close to the sun, which causes them to heat up. When this happens, they start to spew out dust and gas that stretches away from them in a comet tail that can be millions of miles long. Rarely, a comet can be seen with the naked eye.", "According to NASA, the current number of known comets is 3,743. But there are likely to be billions of them orbiting our sun altogether.", "", "
A stock photo shows a man standing with a telescope against a night sky. Livestreams to watch comet C/2021 A1 Leonard are due this month.
